title: How to Do Window Art

steps.headline: Purchase some window paint.
steps.description: Window paints are formulated to stick to glass without beading or running. They dry quickly and can also be removed from the glass easily. Look for window paints at an art supply or craft store near you. You can also purchase window paints online. Some window paints come in applicators that allow you to dab or brush the paint directly onto the window without additional painting tools.

steps.headline: Make your own window paint if you prefer.
steps.description: If you’d rather not purchase window paints, you can easily make your own with basic tempera (“poster paints”) and a little liquid dish soap. The soap will help the paint stick better and make it easier to remove. For the boldest and most durable result, use powdered tempera paints rather than pre-mixed liquid poster paints. Make sure that you mix your paints with soap, NOT detergent. Detergent is caustic and will cause damage to your windows. Use a product such as Ivory concentrated dish washing liquid and hand soap or Meyer’s liquid dish soap. Experiment with using different proportions of paint and dish soap. The more dish soap you use, the runnier the mixture will be. More soap also makes the cleanup easier, however. If you use powdered tempera paints, you will also need to add a little water to the mix. Try adding a tiny amount at first, then increase the amount of water if the mixture is too thick or still powdery.

steps.headline: Select some painting tools.
steps.description: There’s no need to stick to applying your paints with regular brushes. Depending on the effect you want, you can also try sponges, spray bottles (for more liquidy paints), or even homemade stamps. If you don’t want to apply your design free-hand, you can buy or make stencils to help guide your application. If you wish, you can purchase brushes that are specifically made for painting glass or ceramic. These brushes are made with soft hair and are designed to provide smooth coverage. You can also purchase sponge daubers that are designed for use with glass stencils.

steps.headline: Plan out your design if you wish.
steps.description: There’s nothing wrong with doing your painting free-hand if you’re feeling spontaneous. If you have a very specific idea of what you’d like to do, however, it may be a good idea to sketch out a design in advance. Keep in mind factors such as how much space you would like to fill, what colors you would like to use, and where each element of the design will be placed within the window pane.

steps.headline: Place your paints in containers.
steps.description: Before you start painting, put your paints in containers you can easily fit your application tools into. If you’re using brushes, plastic cups should work fine. For larger tools, such as sponges, stamps, or rollers, you may wish to use bowls or trays.

steps.headline: Paint on the side of the window from which the painting will be viewed.
steps.description: If your paint is on the other side of the glass from the viewer, it will be difficult to see. For example, designs meant to be viewed from the outside will be hidden by glare if painted on the interior side of the glass. If you paint your design on the outside of the window, it may appear muted and dim from the inside.

steps.headline: Block out big areas of color first, then outline.
steps.description: If you’re planning to add outlines to your design, it will be easiest to do that after you make your major shapes. Otherwise, your outlines may get covered up when you try to fill them in. Use larger brushes or applicators to fill in big areas of color, and small or detail brushes for outlines, highlights, and other fine details.

steps.headline: Use masking tape or stencils to create crisp edges.
steps.description: If you want really precise control of your edges, stencils or tape are great options. You can buy pre-made painting stencils at art or craft supply stores, or make your own if you prefer. For geometric designs and straight edges, use masking tape to cover parts of the window you don’t want to paint, then peel it off when you’re done. Adhesive stencils are great for window painting, because they will stick in place until you’re ready to take them off. You can also tape a non-adhesive stencil in place with a little masking tape.

steps.headline: Clean off the paint with white vinegar and water.
steps.description: When you’re ready to remove your design, or if you want to clean off spills or excess paint, mix 1 part white vinegar with 1 part water. This mixture may be more effective if you heat it up in a sauce pan, but take care not to burn yourself. Dip a rag into the dilute vinegar and gently wipe away the paint. Put down a drop cloth to protect your windowsill and floor while you clean. If the paint is really stubborn, you can very gently scrape it off with a razor blade.

steps.headline: Draw with chalk markers for a washable, chalky finish.
steps.description: There are a variety of tools on the market designed to draw and write on glass. Visit your local art supply store or do an online search for “glass markers” or “glass pens.” Chalk markers, which contain a liquid ink that dries with a chalky finish, are one of the most popular options. Chalk markers come in a wide variety of colors. You can get vibrant neon shades and even metallic finishes (such as copper, silver, and gold). Some chalk markers have a creamy, crayon-like texture rather than liquid ink. These markers glide on more smoothly, but are more transparent than liquid chalk. There are a variety of formulations of chalk ink, and some are made to be more permanent than others. Some can wipe away easily with water or glass cleaner, while others may need to be removed with an ammonia-based cleaner. Check the label for cleaning instructions.

steps.headline: Use industrial markers if you want your art to be permanent.
steps.description: Industrial markers are designed to write on almost any surface and stand up to moisture and extreme temperatures. If you want to remove the art eventually, make sure to select a marker that is water soluble or washable. Industrial markers may contain liquid ink, or they may come in the form of a solid paint stick or crayon. Make sure to plan your design in advance if you choose this method, since mistakes may be difficult to fix. Be careful not to let the markers get on other surfaces, such as your walls, curtains, or windowsills.

steps.headline: Try marking pencils for a delicate, subtle effect.
steps.description: Marking pencils are soft-graphite colored pencils that are designed to mark on almost any surface. These pencils go on smoothly and can be wiped away with a damp cloth. These are ideal for doing subtle designs and fine detail work.

steps.headline: Choose paint markers for a bold, glossy finish.
steps.description: There are a variety of paint markers on the market that can draw on glass. While some of them are easily washable, others are more permanent, so check the label carefully before you use them. While some paint markers have a regular marker tip, others have a brush tip for a more painterly effect.

steps.headline: Plan your design in advance if you’re using permanent markers.
steps.description: If you’re feeling spontaneous, chalk markers or some other easy-to-clean marker is your best bet. If you’re using a more permanent marker, however, like an industrial marker or a paint marker, it is probably best to have a clear idea of what you are doing before you start marking. Consider what you want to draw, what colors you would like to use, where you’d like to place your design, and how much of the window surface you’d like to cover. If you’re worried about messing up, sketch your design on the window with a grease pencil before you start working with a more permanent marker or pen. The design possibilities are limited only by your imagination! You might write messages in fun scripts, draw designs like flowers and butterflies, or do abstract geometric shapes.

steps.headline: Draw on the side of the window where you want the art to be seen.
steps.description: For example, if you want your drawing to be visible from the outside, draw on the outside of the window. Otherwise, glare will make your drawing difficult to see. If you’re worried about your design getting washed away by rain, use a water-resistant glass marker or make sure the window is protected by an awning.

steps.headline: Purchase premade decals for a ready-made design.
steps.description: Window decals are available in a wide variety of sizes, designs, and colors, and many can be easily removed and reused. If you want some quick and easy window art, this is a good option. Check in your local arts and crafts store or in the home décor section of a department store. You can also order window decals in a huge variety of designs online.

steps.headline: Make your own window decals if you’re feeling more creative.
steps.description: You can easily make your own window decals using puff paint or a mixture of school glue, dish soap, and food coloring. Mix in a little glitter for extra pizzazz, if you wish. To make a window cling with glue, mix 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of school glue with 2 drops of liquid dish soap. (Be sure to use dish soap, not dish detergent.) Add a few drops of the food coloring of your choice. For an opaque design, use acrylic paint instead of food coloring. Draw your design on a regular piece of paper, then cover it with a sheet of parchment paper, wax paper, or plastic. Apply your puff paint or glue mixture to the cover sheet, following the outline of the design underneath. After your design dries, peel it off the backing and apply it to the window wherever you wish.

steps.headline: Arrange your decals however you like.
steps.description: For a spontaneous look, place a few decals randomly around your window. For a more unified design, arrange them in a pattern. For example, if you’re decorating for fall, you might make a garland of autumn leaf decals around the edges of your window. For an interesting night sky effect, you could put a sprinkling of glow-in-the-dark star decals all over the surface of your window.

steps.headline: Use construction paper for an opaque design.
steps.description: Construction paper or colored poster paper are great materials for making simple cutout window decorations. Choose bold colors if you want your designs to be easily visible from the inside or outside. If you’d rather not make your own, you can purchase premade paper decorations from arts and crafts stores or online. Construction paper or other forms of heavy paper will block light coming through your window. You can create interesting effects with light and shadow by covering most of your window with the paper and cutting designs into the paper where you want the light to shine through.

steps.headline: Choose colored tissue paper for a “stained glass” effect.
steps.description: Tissue paper is more translucent than regular paper or heavy cardstock. Light will shine through the tissue paper and create a beautiful glow. Look for colored tissue paper in an arts and crafts store, or get some gift wrap tissue paper from the greeting cards and gifts section in your grocery store or big box store.

steps.headline: Draw your design on the paper of your choice.
steps.description: Use a pencil, pen or marker to sketch your design on the paper. If you’d rather not draw freehand, you can use a stencil or even a cookie cutter to guide you. For example, if you’d like to make some simple heart shapes, you can just place a heart-shaped cookie cutter on top of your paper and trace the outline. You can also download and print out paper cutout templates from the Internet. Lay the template on top of your paper and fix it in place with some tape or a glue stick and cut where indicated.

steps.headline: Cut out your designs.
steps.description: Once you have your design laid out, use a pair of paper-cutting scissors to carefully cut out your shapes. If your design is delicate or has a lot of interior detail, you may need to use a sharp craft knife or utility knife. If you are a child, ask an adult to help you with any sharp cutting tools.

steps.headline: Use tape or clear contact paper to fix your decorations to the window.
steps.description: Once your decorations are cut out, it’s time to put them in place! The simplest approach is to tape the decorations in place with a little clear cellophane tape. You can also fix the decorations to the sticky side of a piece of clear contact paper cut to fit the window, then carefully apply the contact paper to the inside of your window. You can also stick the cutouts to the glass with double-sided tape. Place the decorations on the inside of your window. If you put paper decorations on an exterior window, they may quickly become rain damaged or fade in the sun.

For example, if you’re decorating for fall, you might make a garland of autumn leaf decals around the edges of your window.
For an interesting night sky effect, you could put a sprinkling of glow-in-the-dark star decals all over the surface of your window.
Decorating with Paper Cutouts Use construction paper for an opaque design.
Construction paper or colored poster paper are great materials for making simple cutout window decorations.
Choose bold colors if you want your designs to be easily visible from the inside or outside.
If you’d rather not make your own, you can purchase premade paper decorations from arts and crafts stores or online.
Construction paper or other forms of heavy paper will block light coming through your window.
You can create interesting effects with light and shadow by covering most of your window with the paper and cutting designs into the paper where you want the light to shine through.
Choose colored tissue paper for a “stained glass” effect.
Tissue paper is more translucent than regular paper or heavy cardstock.
Light will shine through the tissue paper and create a beautiful glow.
Look for colored tissue paper in an arts and crafts store, or get some gift wrap tissue paper from the greeting cards and gifts section in your grocery store or big box store.
Draw your design on the paper of your choice.
Use a pencil, pen or marker to sketch your design on the paper.
If you’d rather not draw freehand, you can use a stencil or even a cookie cutter to guide you.
For example, if you’d like to make some simple heart shapes, you can just place a heart-shaped cookie cutter on top of your paper and trace the outline.
You can also download and print out paper cutout templates from the Internet.
Lay the template on top of your paper and fix it in place with some tape or a glue stick and cut where indicated.
Cut out your designs.
Once you have your design laid out, use a pair of paper-cutting scissors to carefully cut out your shapes.
If your design is delicate or has a lot of interior detail, you may need to use a sharp craft knife or utility knife.
If you are a child, ask an adult to help you with any sharp cutting tools.
Use tape or clear contact paper to fix your decorations to the window.
Once your decorations are cut out, it’s time to put them in place!
The simplest approach is to tape the decorations in place with a little clear cellophane tape.
You can also fix the decorations to the sticky side of a piece of clear contact paper cut to fit the window, then carefully apply the contact paper to the inside of your window.
You can also stick the cutouts to the glass with double-sided tape.
Place the decorations on the inside of your window.
If you put paper decorations on an exterior window, they may quickly become rain damaged or fade in the sun.
